article:
'Situated cognition' is a theory that poses that knowing is inseparable from
doing John Seely Brown, Collins, & Duguid, 1989; Greeno, 1989 by
arguing that all knowledge is situated in activity bound to social, cultural and
physical contexts. Greeno & Moore, 1993

Under this assumption, which requires an epistemological shift from empiricism,
situativity theorists suggest a model of knowledge and learning that requires
thinking on the fly rather than the storage and retrieval of conceptual
knowledge. In essence, cognition cannot be separated from the context. Instead
knowing exists, in situ, inseparable from context, activity, people, culture,
and language. Therefore, learning is seen in terms of an individual's
increasingly effective performance across situations rather than in terms of an
accumulation of knowledge, since what is known is co-determined by the agent
and the context. This perspective rejects mind-body dualism and person-
environment dualism.
